item.title: Covid: Lockdown easing in England to be delayed by four weeks
item.description: Most current Covid rules will remain for four more weeks after 21 June, government sources say.

item.title: No evidence Bashir rehired as cover-up - BBC report
item.description: The inquiry was commissioned by the BBC after a report into how Bashir got his 1995 Diana interview.

item.title: Headache and runny nose linked to Delta variant
item.description: People may need to be on the lookout for different Covid symptoms, according to researchers.

item.title: Ethiopian migrants face robbery, extortion and starvation
item.description: Every year thousands of migrants risk it all on the perilous journey from Ethiopia to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Jess Phillips: Ditch HPV stigma to avoid the shame I felt
item.description: With more women being told they have the virus, Jess Phillips says there needs to be more discussion.

item.title: Arlene Foster urges NI parties to stick to language deal
item.description: Arlene Foster made a personal statement to the NI Assembly before she resigned as first minister.

item.title: Ned Beatty, Deliverance, Superman and Toy Story 3 actor, dies aged 83
item.description: Dubbed the busiest actor in Hollywood, he was also seen in Nashville, Network and many other films.

item.title: Buxted FC: Vandals smash defibrillator kit after Eriksen collapse
item.description: A 17-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of causing criminal damage after Sunday's attack.

item.title: Blood donation: Gay couple 'thrilled' after rules change
item.description: Until now men who have sex with men had to wait three months before donating.

item.title: Covid vaccination: All adults in Wales offered first jab
item.description: Welsh health minister says vaccine rollout is six weeks ahead of schedule as Wales leads world.

item.title: Nato summit: Nato must face up to China's rise, alliance chief says
item.description: A summit of alliance leaders is expected to describe China's behaviour as a "systemic challenge".

item.title: ‘Really, really rare’ seahorse spotted off UK coast
item.description: A marine biologist says it’s the first time he’s ever seen a long-snouted seahorse in the wild.

item.title: The gay men who can donate blood in the UK for the first time
item.description: Gay couple Oscar and Xavier donate blood for the first time after rules change across most of the UK.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: Dad back playing football after cardiac arrest
item.description: Andrew Barnett had a cardiac arrest while playing football in front of his son in 2018.

item.title: Oops, wrong chair: Netanyahu sits in PM's chair after loss
item.description: After a vote installing a new government, Benjamin Netanyahu sat back down, but in a seat that was no longer his.

item.title: ASMR: Former farmer, 84, is accidental YouTube star
item.description: John Butler's videos have been watched by millions after he became popular with the ASMR community.

item.title: E3 2021: Microsoft shows off Halo Infinite, Starfield and Forza Horizon 5
item.description: A release date for Halo, a new Forza racer, and the unveil of Starfield were all at Microsoft's E3.

item.title: In pictures: World leaders bask in Cornwall sun at G7 summit
item.description: World leaders are by the seaside for three days of talks - and the occasional trip to the beach...

item.title: ICYMI: Squirrel security and an unusual pitch invader
item.description: From a squirrel security guard to an unusual mid-match disruption, here are some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Tourette’s Syndrome: ‘I don’t want people to think I’m a bad child’
item.description: Ten-year-old Deaglan McCallion wants people to be more understanding of his condition.

item.title: 'We want another homeless hotel - and we can make it work'
item.description: The Holiday Inn in Gorton, Manchester, housed homeless people throughout the pandemic, until the end of May.

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: The buzzwords reflecting the frustration of China's young generation
item.description: Millions in China are expressing their desire to break free of a standard definition of success.

item.title: Euro 2020: The ways Scotland has changed since France '98
item.description: When Scotland's men last played in a major football tournament, there was no Scottish Parliament and Google didn't exist.

item.title: Tech firms use remote monitoring to help honey bees
item.description: From Ireland to Israel, companies are coming to the aid of the environmentally critical insect.

item.title: What Putin really wants from Biden
item.description: The Geneva summit on 16 June between the Russian and US presidents will not be a friendly encounter.

item.title: Netanyahu: A shrewd leader who reshaped Israel
item.description: Loved and loathed, Israel's ousted long-term PM made his mark on the country at home and abroad.

item.title: G7 summit: How significant are group's climate pledges?
item.description: G7 leaders make new pledges to combat climate change, but campaigners say they lack detail.

item.title: Euro 2020: Five-goal Netherlands thriller an uplifting end to traumatic weekend
item.description: After a harrowing 36 hours for European football following Christian Eriksen's collapse, the Netherland and Ukraine served up a Euro 2020 classic.

item.title: Murray 'not offending anyone' by continuing to play despite injury problems
item.description: Andy Murray says he is "not offending anyone" by continuing to play despite injury problems and says seeing Roger Federer still playing motivates him.

item.title: 'No more room for England excuses as India and Australia loom large'
item.description: Thumped by New Zealand, England have precious little time - and decreasing goodwill - as they prepare for two huge Test series later this year.

item.title: Euro 2020: Tomas Vaclik denies Andy Robertson with fingertip save
item.description: Scotland captain Andy Robertson hits a first time strike but Czech Republic keeper Tomas Vaclik is able to push it wide during their Euro 2020 tie.

item.title: Euro 2020: Biffy Clyro chart Scotland's long wait for a major men's tournament
item.description: Rock band Biffy Clyro chart Scotland's long and painful wait to play at a major international men's football tournament with a special performance of 'Now I'm Everyone'.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: 'Heat of moment' decision to play should not have been made - Kasper Schmeichel
item.description: Goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel says the decision to resume the game between Denmark and Finland at Euro 2020 should not have been made so soon after Christian Eriksen's collapse.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government is yet to decide whether to lift the remaining restrictions on 21 June.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: When could social distancing end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: Steve Clarke: Scotland manager by those who know him best
item.description: BBC Scotland speaks to those who know Steve Clarke best to find out about the man who is about to end the nation's 23-year wait for a major men's finals.

item.title: England 1-0 Croatia: 'Southgate got big calls exactly right'
item.description: England boss Gareth Southgate's opening team selection of Euro 2020 offered up plenty of debating points - but he got it right, says Phil McNulty.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: Resuming Denmark-Finland match was 'least bad decision', says Martin Braithwaite
item.description: Denmark forward Martin Braithwaite says the decision to resume Denmark's Euro 2020 opener against Finland following Christian Eriksen's cardiac arrest was the "least bad one".

item.title: Euro 2020: England put a smile on our faces against Croatia - Alan Shearer
item.description: Former England captain and BBC Sport columnist Alan Shearer says Sunday's win over Croatia was a reminder of how England can benefit from playing at Wembley.

item.title: Euro 2020 England 1-0 Croatia: Raheem Sterling was brightest spark - Rio Ferdinand
item.description: BBC Sport pundit Rio Ferdinand says Raheem Sterling "was the brightest spark" in England's opening game against Croatia.
